title: John Louis Morkovsky
text:
John Ludvik Morkovsky (August 16, 1909 – March 24, 1990) was a <a href="Czech%20American">Czech American</a> <a href="prelate">prelate</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. He served as <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Amarillo">Bishop of Amarillo</a> (1958–1963) and <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Galveston-Houston">Bishop of Galveston-Houston</a> (1975–1984).
Early life and education.
The seventh of ten children, John Morkovsky was born in <a href="Praha%2C%20Texas">Praha</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, to Alois and Marie (née Raska) Morkovsky. His father came directly to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> from <a href="Moravia">Moravia</a>, while his mother was the daughter of Moravian immigrants. He was <a href="Baptism">baptized</a> by Rev. <a href="http%3A//www.txgenweb3.org/txfayette/biographies_n-r.htm%23netardus">Louis P. Netardus</a> at his parents' home. He attended St. John's Seminary in <a href="San%20Antonio%2C%20Texas">San Antonio</a> from 1924 until 1930, when he was sent to further his studies in <a href="Rome">Rome</a> at the <a href="Pontifical%20Urbaniana%20University">College of the Propaganda</a> and the <a href="Pontifical%20Gregorian%20University">Pontifical Gregorian University</a>.
Priesthood.
While in Rome, Morkovsky was <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> to the <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priesthood</a> by Cardinal <a href="Francesco%20Marchetti%20Selvaggiani">Francesco Marchetti Selvaggiani</a> on December 5, 1933. He later earned his <a href="Doctor%20of%20Sacred%20Theology">doctorate in theology</a> in 1936. Upon his return to Texas in 1936, Morkovsky served as a <a href="curate">curate</a> at <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110715043751/http%3A//www.ourladyoflourdesvictoria.parishesonline.com/scripts/HostedSites/Org.asp%3FID%3D13565">St. Michael's Church</a> in <a href="Weimar%2C%20Texas">Weimar</a> until 1939. He was a curate at <a href="http%3A//www.stanncatholicchurch.com/">St. Anne's Church</a> in San Antonio from 1939 to 1940, and a <a href="professor">professor</a> of <a href="Canon%20law%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">canon law</a>, <a href="Latin">Latin</a> and <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a> at St. John's Seminary from 1940 to 1941. He briefly served as <a href="pastor">pastor</a> of <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110716142347/http%3A//www.stfrancissandiego.com/">St. Francis de Paula Church</a> and <a href="Superintendent%20%28education%29">superintendent</a> of <a href="Catholic%20school">Catholic school</a>s in San Antonio.
From 1941 to 1943, Morkovsky attended the <a href="The%20Catholic%20University%20of%20America">Catholic University of America</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, from where he obtained a <a href="Master%20of%20Arts">Master of Arts</a> degree in <a href="education">education</a>. He then resumed his duties as superintendent in San Antonio, in which capacity he remained until 1956. During that time, he also served as <a href="judge">judge</a> of the archdiocesan <a href="Ecclesiastical%20court">matrimonial court</a> (1944–56), pastor of <a href="http%3A//www.stleochurch.com/">St. Leo's Church</a> in San Antonio (1945–54), archdiocesan <a href="consultor">consultor</a> (1947–56), and pastor of <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110715045604/http%3A//www.parishesonline.com/Scripts/HostedSites/Org.asp%3FID%3D3695">St. Mary Magdalene's Church</a> in San Antonio (1954–56). He was also moderator of the San Antonio Deanery Council of Catholic Women and director of the <a href="National%20Legion%20of%20Decency">Legion of Decency</a>, and organized the Federation of Catholic Parents' and Teachers' Clubs in San Antonio.
Episcopal ministry.
Amarillo.
On December 22, 1955, Morkovsky was appointed <a href="Auxiliary%20Bishop">Auxiliary Bishop</a> of <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Amarillo">Amarillo</a> and <a href="Titular%20Bishop">Titular Bishop</a> of "Hieron" by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20XII">Pope Pius XII</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">episcopal</a> <a href="consecration">consecration</a> on February 22, 1956 from Archbishop <a href="Amleto%20Giovanni%20Cicognani">Amleto Giovanni Cicognani</a>, with Bishops <a href="Mariano%20Simon%20Garriga">Mariano Simon Garriga</a> and <a href="Sidney%20Matthew%20Metzger">Sidney Matthew Metzger</a> serving as <a href="Consecrator">co-consecrators</a>. In addition to his duties as auxiliary bishop, he also served as <a href="Chancellor%20%28ecclesiastical%29">chancellor</a> and <a href="vicar%20general">vicar general</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Amarillo">Diocese of Amarillo</a>.
Less than two months before his death, Pius XII named Morkovsky the fourth <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Amarillo">Bishop of Amarillo</a> on August 18, 1958. He remained in Amarillo as the spiritual leader of Catholics in the <a href="Texas%20Panhandle">Texas Panhandle</a> for four years.
Galveston-Houston.
On April 16, 1963, Morkovsky was appointed <a href="Coadjutor%20Bishop">Coadjutor Bishop</a> of <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Galveston-Houston">Galveston-Houston</a> and Titular Bishop of "Tigava" by the ailing <a href="Pope%20John%20XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a>. He became <a href="Apostolic%20Administrator">Apostolic Administrator</a> of the diocese under Bishop <a href="Wendelin%20Joseph%20Nold">Wendelin Joseph Nold</a>, who suffered from near total <a href="blindness">blindness</a>. He also attended the <a href="Second%20Vatican%20Council">Second Vatican Council</a> from 1962 to 1965. In 1964 he founded the diocesan <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a> "The Texas Catholic Herald" and hosted the visit of Cardinal <a href="Josef%20Beran">Josef Beran</a>. He established the first diocesan <a href="Catholic%20missions">mission</a> in <a href="Guatemala%20City">Guatemala City</a> in 1966, and the Hospital <a href="Chaplain">Chaplain</a>s Corps at <a href="http%3A//www.hhc.org/">Houston Medical Center</a> in 1968. From 1970 to 1972, he was the first Catholic bishop to preside over the <a href="http%3A//www.txconfchurches.org/">Texas Conference of Churches</a>.
Morkovsky later succeeded Nold as the sixth <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Galveston-Houston">Bishop of Galveston-Houston</a> on April 22, 1975. During his tenure, he established <a href="African%20American">African American</a> and <a href="Mexican%20American">Mexican American</a> ministries and gave special attention to low-income parishioners and Houston's large <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>ese community. The Catholic Church in Texas continued to experience tremendous growth which led to further divisions of the diocese, including the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Beaumont">Diocese of Beaumont</a> (1966), <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Victoria%20in%20Texas">Victoria</a> (1982), and <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Tyler">Tyler</a> (1987).
Later life and death.
After nine years as diocesan bishop, Morkovsky resigned on August 21, 1984. He continued to live in his home on the grounds of St. Mary's Seminary in <a href="Houston%2C%20Texas">Houston</a>. At age 80, he died from a <a href="stroke">stroke</a> in <a href="Tacoma%2C%20Washington">Tacoma, Washington</a>, where he was visiting relatives. He is buried at Holy Cross Cemetery in Houston.
